docs.lead_paragraph: The inhaled steroids that enable asthma patients to breathe easier will not do much to help people with lung disease from years of smoking. Doctors had hypothesized that inhaled steroids might help such people because, like asthma patients, they suffer shortness of breath.

headline.main: Steroids Fail to Aid Diseased Smokers

docs.abstract: Two studies reported in New England Journal of Medicine find that inhaled steroids do little to help people with lung disease from years of smoking; Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reports more than 106,000 people die of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, a combination of chronic bronchitis and emphysema (S)

keywords.value: CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION

docs.lead_paragraph: You can get it mowing the lawn, whacking weeds, petting the dog, hiking through the woods, burning logs in a fireplace, gardening, retrieving a lost ball, using the great outdoors for a toilet, putting clothes in the washing machine or removing your shoes. ''It'' is poison ivy, a source of misery for half the people who make contact with its allergenic sap and a potential problem for many more people who are not yet sensitized. As you can see from the above list of possible exposures, poison ivy dermatitis is not so easy to avoid. However, prevention is possible, and when that fails, quick recognition of an incipient outbreak and appropriate action can greatly reduce its severity and resulting discomfort. Unfortunately, myths and misconceptions about this perennial problem abound and all too often result in extensive outbreaks that require medical attention.

headline.main: Quick Action Eases Sting of Poison Ivy

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column focuses on prevention and treatment of poison ivy; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: As evidence that the earth's atmosphere is warming continues to accumulate, scientists are making slow progress toward an answer to the big question raised by the evidence: how much of the warming is due to human activity and how much to natural causes? The United Nations' Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, the group of scientists widely considered the most authoritative voice on the subject, has already concluded that there is a ''discernible human influence'' on the global climate. Now the panel is deep into another of its periodic full-scale scientific assessments of global climate change, to be finished in about 18 months. While the group's conclusions are unformed, some experts on the problem say the human imprint on climate is becoming clearer, and may even have been the dominant factor in the global warming of recent decades. Not everyone agrees -- there is a range of judgments -- and virtually all experts say that in any case, a reliable estimate of the human imprint's magnitude still remains some distance off.

headline.main: Human Imprint on Climate Change Grows Clearer

docs.abstract: As earth's atmosphere continues to warm, scientists make some progress toward answering how much of warming is due to human activity and how much to natural causes; United Nations' Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change has concluded there is 'discernible human influence' on global climate; at issue is magnitude of human imprint; while earth's average surface temperature has warmed, warming has not been geographically uniform; many influences combine to produce different temperature profiles at different times; maps (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: One afternoon recently when I was working in my outpatient clinic, a middle-aged woman came to me with a surprise. The severe lower back pain and leg pain and numbness that had plagued her for months, making it impossible for her even to sit in a chair on recent clinic visits, had all but disappeared. She informed me that she had canceled her back surgery scheduled for later in the month. But all was not well. Her neck and shoulder, only mildly bothersome on recent visits, now ached as if in a vise. Her left arm was almost entirely numb, except for shooting pains when she flexed her neck. Though an M.R.I. last month had been normal, I was certain this unfortunate woman had pinched a nerve in her neck, probably from a herniated disc.

headline.main: When the Truth Is as Elusive as the Cure

docs.lead_paragraph: Cooks know that marinating a steak before grilling improves flavor and tenderizes. Now, scientists suggest the technique decreases the production of carcinogenic compounds in meats and fish cooked at high temperatures. ''We really don't know what magic bullet in the marinade reduces it,'' said Mark G. Knize, a Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory scientist, who tested recipes and products to find the effects of marinade on meat. He and his colleagues stumbled onto it as a small part of a a study financed by the National Cancer Institute.
docs.abstract: Scientists suggest that marinating before grilling decreases production of carcinogenic compounds in meats and fish cooked at high temperatures; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: With the deliberations in full swing for revisions of the Federal Dietary Guidelines for All Americans, to be reissued next year, what started as a controversy is fast progressing into a contentious argument: should the Government be recommending dairy products as part of a balanced diet, given that once most nonwhite people leave childhood, they cannot easily digest those products? Led by groups like the Congressional Black Caucus, a growing chorus of health and civil rights organizations are saying no, and calling for reworked guidelines that reflect the nation's digestive diversity.

headline.main: Groups Debate Role of Milk In Building a Better Pyramid

docs.abstract: Controversy over role of milk has arisen as Government revises its Federal Dietary Guidelines for All Americans; growing chorus of health and civil rights organizations say reworked guidelines should reflect nation's digestive diversity, including lactose intolerance of large numbers of nonwhite Americans; nation's dairy industry is resisting such a move, as is Department of Agriculture, whose dual mandate is to advise consumers about good eating while promoting American farm products; dairy products are rich source of calcium, but they are not only source of calcium; graph (M)
docs.snippet: With the deliberations in full swing for revisions of the Federal Dietary Guidelines for All Americans, to be reissued next year, what started as a controversy is fast progressing into  a contentious argument: should the Government be recommending...

docs.lead_paragraph: Though aficionados of trampolining hope that the Olympics will inspire children to participate in the sport, some doctors do not share their enthusiasm. The American Academy of Pediatrics, citing an estimated 83,400 trampoline-related injuries in 1996, recently reiterated its 1981 position that the equipment should not be used in homes, in routine physical education classes or on playgrounds. Several studies show that injuries occur when children land incorrectly on the trampoline, hit the frame or springs, fall or collide with another person. Nationally, about one child dies a year from trampolining injuries.

docs.lead_paragraph: Jennifer Jako once had a ''not me'' attitude about AIDS. ''I really was an unlikely candidate for this disease,'' Ms. Jako, an AIDS educator and documentary film producer, said in a panel discussion in New York last week. ''I didn't think this would happen to me.''

headline.main: Young People Open to H.I.V. Testing

docs.lead_paragraph: Minority group members, the poor and people who contracted AIDS through drug use are less likely to get needed care, including drugs that have prolonged life for thousands of people, according to the first national study of AIDS treatment. The disparities were particularly acute in 1996, when the study began, but diminished somewhat over two years. Still, the gap persisted for some groups, including women.

headline.main: Study Shows Disparities in AIDS Care

docs.abstract: First national study of AIDS treatment finds that minority group members, poor and people who contract disease through drug use are less likely to get needed care, including drugs that have prolonged life for thousands of people (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Q. Are physical performance standards discriminatory when used as criteria in hiring? ALISHA BERGER Pre-employment physical fitness tests are discriminatory. More than 100 physiological differences have been found between men and women, making it virtually impossible to construct a test that is fair to box sexes or that yields results that can meaningfully be applied to the work site.

headline.main: Physical Fitness As a Job Yardstick

docs.abstract: Dr James A Peterson and Dr Andrew S Jackson argue for and against using physical performance standards as criteria in hiring; drawing (S)
